msDesc.physDesc: This letter is one page long. The heading is “Miss Harriet Monroe, Editor “Poetry” 543 Cass Street Chicago, Illinois”. The year has a handwritten “1” before the 8, indicating it was 1918. The letter is typed on plain white paper; it is not creased.

div.p: Thank you ever so much for your nice letter. The operation was done last Thursday, and I am, as you see, once more able to dictate letters but I am not able to do anything else, and I am beginning to feel as if I were nailed into bed and were never going to be able to get out of it. However, I shall certainly take your advice, for I know it is good, and sit here until all danger of overdoing is past. In fact, my doctor is a perfect old curmudgeon and refuses to let me up for at least a week more and not downstairs for an indefinite time after that. He says that he is going to have no lingering effects from this operation.

I am awfully glad that you like Florence Ayscough’s and my Chinese poems. I should have told you that of course I will correct the proof, and you can send the money to me, and all those little details, and I will divvy up with her, according to arrangements.
I am getting more and more thrilled about the book that we are going to publish after the war, mostly Florence, of course, but with me to help on these renderings. I think it will be interesting.
With many thanks for your solicitude,
